Helps clients make critical data driven decisions.

On this LGBT+ Initiatives page of Diversity & Inclusion learn more about how our strategy is designed to engage, support and advance our LGBT+ professionals and promote an inclusive and accepting work environment.
record.pwc_body: LGBT+ Initiatives LGBT+ Our LGBT+ (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, +) professionals are an important community within PwC and with our clients. The firm’s strategy is designed to engage, support and advance our LGBT+ professionals and promote an inclusive and accepting work environment. We take action by • Having an LGBT+ Partner Advisory Board since 2004 that raises visibility of the LGBT+ community within PwC and makes policy recommendations for how the firm can attract, retain and advance LGBT+ professionals. • Providing full domestic partner benefit coverage and programs that support a broad range of family needs, including adoption and surrogacy. • Proudly supporting the transgender community and its allies. We joined 180 other CEOs and corporate leaders who are calling for respect for all and equality under the law for transgender, gender non-binary and intersex people. • Providing professional development opportunities for LGBT+ staff via the national and global LGBT+ summits and through our external partnerships to convene our LGBT+ community. • Connecting LGBT+ professionals with allies, learners, members and supporters through our Shine Network. Resources • Highlighted partnerships - GLAAD, Human Rights Campaign (HRC), OutLeadership and The Trevor Project • LGBT+ timeline • PwC sponsored research with OutLeadership - Out to Succeed and Visibility Counts • Pursuit of Happiness Podcast - Gender Inclusion with Jean Malpas from the Ackerman Institute • Workplace gender inclusivity and transition guidelines • Find additional resources in the Shine Network • Office of Diversity Contacts Our Initiatives Disability & Caregivers Gender Minorities Parenting Veterans

record.pwc_description: On this subpage of Diversity & Inclusion learn more about what our diversity and inclusion efforts mean for our clients.
record.pwc_body: D&I Clients Clients and D&I Clients often ask about PwC’s diversity efforts. They want our engagement teams to reflect the diversity within their own organizations, and to know that we leverage it to deliver high-quality service. Our diverse client service teams solve problems and bring solutions to our clients. Talking to clients about D&I We encourage you to engage clients around diversity and inclusion. The tools in this section are all external and intended to be shared with clients: • Ability Reveals Itself Impact Report • Blind spots video series • CEO Action (encourage clients to take the ‘I Act on Pledge’ and follow the Check Your Blind Spots Unconscious Bias Mobile Tour) • Global diversity & inclusion survey • Implicit Association Tests (IAT) • Outsmarting Human Minds series • Pursuit of Happiness podcast • Workforce of the Future Requests for Proposals (RFPs) RFPs often ask about the firm's diversity programs and demographics. We designed an internal toolkit, Diversity Opens Doors, to support teams as they create RFPs. If your client requests a D&I conversation or diversity data, please reach out to your Market Diversity Leader to discuss. Supplier Diversity PwC recognizes that our diversity efforts have a positive economic impact on the communities where we do business. Through our Supplier Diversity initiative, we look for diverse companies to add to our supply chain and complement the services we provide our clients. PwC partners with business enterprises that are qualified and certified as minority-owned (MBE), women-owned (WBE), disability-owned (DBE), veteran-owned (VBE) and lesbian/gay/bisexual/transgender-owned (LGBT+). The firm also supports organizations and programs that certify, train and develop diverse suppliers. And, we help our clients meet their own supplier diversity requirements. Requests for proposals from our clients often call for strategies to include diverse suppliers; we work closely with these firms during the contracting process. In addition to helping our clients, we're providing support to the communities where we do business and promoting economic development in a fast-growing segment of the population. Our Initiatives Disability & Caregivers Gender LGBT+ Minorities Parenting Veterans

record.pwc_description: On this Minorities Initiatives page of Diversity & Inclusion learn more about our diversity programs aimed at attracting, retaining, and advancing talented minority staff and partners.
record.pwc_body: Minority Initiatives Minorities We know diverse teams are more innovative and create more impactful solutions. We seek to attract, retain, develop and advance talented minority staff and partners through our diversity programs. We support early career success through learning resources focused on individuals' unique experiences. We take action by • Promoting cultural awareness education to enhance global acumen. Our programs provide access to role models & mentors to provide career coaching and guidance. • Hosting Signature Leadership Experiences designed to help diverse, high-performing professionals accelerate their success and reach even higher in their careers. • Providing opportunities to broaden their networks by participating with strategic external sponsorships with diverse organizations that focus on leadership development. • Connecting our professionals with students to help continue to attract and recruit top talent to PwC. • Embedding a diversity and inclusion lens into all aspects of the career lifecycle. • Connecting minorities with allies, learners, members and supporters through our Black Inclusion Network (BIN), Latino Inclusion Network (LIN) and Pan Asian Community Inclusion Network (PACIN). Resources • Blind spots video series • Highlighted partnerships -- ALPFA, Ascend, NABA, Tanenbaum and Multicultural Women’s Conference • Add holiday and cultural observances to your calendar • Outsmarting Human Minds • Responsible Business Leadership -- Access Your Potential and Dollars for Doers • Talent Acquisition initiatives -- Start, Career Preview, Howard University Center for Accounting Education • Find additional resources in the Black Inclusion Network (BIN), Latino Inclusion Network (LIN) and Pan Asian Community Inclusion Network (PACIN) • Office of Diversity Contacts Our Initiatives Disability & Caregivers Gender LGBT+ Parenting Veterans

record.pwc_description: On this Veterans Initiatives page of Diversity & Inclusion learn more about the programs we've created to support our veterans, active duty military personnel and their families at work and in the community
record.pwc_body: Veterans Initiatives Veterans PwC understands the depth and breadth of experience veterans bring to our country and our firm. We have created programs that support our veterans, active duty military personnel and their families at work and in the community and we’ve enhanced our veterans initiatives to be a military-friendly professional services employer. We take action by • Creating a community of support for PwC’s veterans and their families, as well as those with loved ones in the military. • Focusing on five key areas: veteran recruiting; outreach and networking for personal and professional development and community service opportunities; education; mentorship and family readiness. • Providing mentorship opportunities through the VAN Mentorship Program, which offers newly-hired PwC veterans an opportunity to develop a relationship with and be formally mentored by more-experienced PwC veterans on matters of personal and professional development. • Connecting veterans with allies, learners, members and supporters through our Veterans Affinity Network (VAN). Resources • Military and Veterans recruiting • Highlighted partnerships - Four Block and Student Veterans of America • PwC Charitable Foundation - Veterans • Find additional resources in the Veterans Affinity Network (VAN) • Office of Diversity Contacts Our Initiatives Disability & Caregivers Gender LGBT+ Minorities Parenting

record.pwc_description: On this Disability & Caregivers Initiatives page of Diversity & Inclusion learn more about how we promote awareness and provides support for employees with disabilities and people caring for family members with disabilities.
record.pwc_body: Disability & Caregivers Disability & caregivers PwC's disability strategy promotes awareness and provides support for employees with disabilities and people caring for family members with disabilities. We take action by Providing disability inclusion awareness training and education. Improving accessibility of physical spaces and digital tools across the firm. Focusing on talent acquisition initiatives including our Neurodiversity Talent Innovation Program. Connecting professionals with disabilities and caregivers with allies, learners, members and supporters through our Abilities and Allies Network. Resources AbilityWorks provides a streamlined process to manage disability-related reasonable accommodation requests for candidates and staff persons across various phases of the employment lifecycle, from recruitment to the everyday enablement of our people having tools and resources they need to work at their best. Ability Reveals Itself Impact Report Abilities and Allies Network: Effective Advocacy Series Partnerships - National Organization on Disability and Disability:IN Neurodiversity Podcast Series Webcast replays: Disability Caregivers and Professionals with Disabilities PwC-sponsored research: Disabilities in the Workplace The Working Mother Report and CTI Disabilities Study Spotlight on Ability Video Series - Learn about people with disabilities and actions each of us can take Additional resources: Abilities and Allies Network Office of Diversity Contacts Our Initiatives Gender LGBT+ Minorities Parenting Veterans

record.pwc_description: On this Parenting Initiatives page of Diversity & Inclusion learn more about our programs, benefits and flexible, supportive culture.
record.pwc_body: Parenting Parenting From parental leave and phased return through backup care support and reimbursement, we are committed to supporting our parents through all phases of caregiving. We take action by • Providing generous leave policies and an innovative phased return to work program. • Programs that support a broad range of family needs including adoption and surrogacy. • Promoting flexibility for everyone and providing specific support for caregivers. • Connecting caregivers with allies, learners, members and supporters through our Parenting Network. Resources • Prepared Parent - one stop shop for policies and programs • Be well, work well • Flexible Work Arrangements • Full Circle program • LiveWell Resources (additional information) • Pursuit of Happiness podcast • Find additional resources in the Parenting Network • Office of Diversity Contacts Our Initiatives Disability & Caregivers Gender LGBT+ Minorities Veterans

record.pwc_description: On this page find out what market and national support networks are available for Diversity & Inclusion.
record.pwc_body: Contacts Contacts Need more information, have questions or want to learn more? We have numerous market and national support networks for our partners and staff: Market Diversity Leader The Market Diversity Leader (MDL) works with market leadership to retain, develop and advance women and diverse talent at PwC. Reach out to your MDL if you: • Want a holistic local market/vertical perspective on our D&I efforts • Would like to build your network of coaches to help you develop and advance your career • Would like to get involved in local D&I efforts • Have questions on any of the available D&I programs or Inclusion Networks MDLs by market: Central Name: TBD Home office: TBD Mid-Atlantic Lety Juan Tysons, VA Midwest Cami Negret Cleveland, OH New York (Assurance/PCS) Rosemary Guider (ToD) New York, NY New York (Assurance/PCS) Amma Osei New York, NY New York (Tax) Lisa Cordova New York, NY New York (Advisory) Paula Theus New York, NY Northeast Allyson Schiller Boston, MA Bay Area Northwest Moire Rasmussen San Francisco, CA Southeast Jackie Martin Atlanta, GA Southwest Henry Brandt Los Angeles, CA Texas Renu Sachdeva Houston, TX LoS D&I Director The LoS D&I Director (LoSDL) serves as the primary diversity advisor to LoS leadership and collaborates with them to drive the D&I strategy within the LoS. The LoSDL has a focus on strategic initiatives to retain, develop, and advance women and minorities, particularly at the senior manager/director level. When would I reach out to my LoSDL? Reach out to your LoSDL anytime you want a better understanding of the specific LoS D&I efforts. In addition, reach out if you: • Would like to build your LoS network of coaches to help you develop and advance your career, particularly at the senior manager/director level • Want to better understand the role and priorities of the LoS Diversity Partner Champion Network • Want to contribute to LoS efforts or offer D&I educational experiences in LoS sector conferences Who are the LoSDLs? (by LoS) Advisory Hannah Wu Assurance Chris Brassell Tax & PCS Raechel Levine Diversity Partner Champion Network The Diversity Partner Champion (DPC) Network is a xLoS team committed to leading our D&I efforts and are a valuable resource for all staff and partners. Each of our markets and go-to-market teams have DPCs who dedicate hundreds of hours working with our recruiting teams, client service professionals and respective D&I leadership teams to drive our efforts. Our DPC network is managed by a D&I Partner Leader for each LoS who guides priorities and focus for their respective LoS. When would I reach out to a DPC? Reach out to your DPC anytime you want a leader’s perspective on our D&I efforts. For example, if you: • Want to better understand the depth and breadth of PwC’s D&I strategy and impact • Are seeking opportunities to get engaged and plugged into local D&I activity and efforts • Need an additional resource to discuss career guidance and leadership support and development Who are the LoS D&I Partner Leaders? (By LoS) Advisory Alie Hoover Assurance Sheri Wyatt PCS Suzanne Fradette Tax Lissett Margarita Tautfest Who is part of the DPC network? Here is the full listing of our network that can be viewed by LoS, Market, or Vertical. • Consolidated Office of Diversity Contacts • Ethics & Compliance Helpline - ask a policy question or report an ethics concern Our Initiatives Disability & Caregivers Gender LGBT+ Minorities Parenting Veterans

record.pwc_description: On this Gender Initiatives page of Diversity & Inclusion learn more about how we strive to attract, retain, develop and advance women at all stages in their careers
record.pwc_body: Gender initiatives Gender We are committed to gender equality. That means we strive to attract, retain, develop and advance women at all stages in their careers. We focus on creating an inclusive culture that develops women to be future leaders. We take action by • Educating our people about gender dynamics in the workplace. • Connecting women with allies, learners, members and supporters through our Women’s Inclusion Network (WIN). • Embedding diversity and inclusion into all aspects of the career lifecycle. • Providing developmental programs for top performing women. • Focusing on women in technology as part of the Your Tomorrow strategy. Resources • All of us: A candid conversation about gender on International Women's Day 2019 (webcast replay) • Candid conversations: Respect in the Workplace podcasts • HeForShe Building Gender IQ online course developed by PwC and UN Women • LeanIn educational resources • Prepared Parent (for policies and programs) • Pursuit of Happiness podcast • Talent Acquisition initiative -- Women's Consulting Experience • Women in Tech -- Digital Upskilling: Tech While You Trek • Find additional resources in the Women Inclusion Network (WIN) • Office of Diversity Contacts Our Initiatives Disability & Caregivers LGBT+ Minorities Parenting Veterans

record.pwc_description: On this Diversity & Inclusion subpage, find out how you can take action, get involved and make an impact.
record.pwc_body: Take action Take action We all play a role in cultivating a culture of inclusion and belonging. Here's how you can get involved and make an impact. I want to get involved with diversity and inclusion nationally or in my local market • Join one of our Inclusion Networks to connect with and learn from your colleagues. Our Inclusion Networks are for everyone - allies, learners, members and supporters. • Learn about and engage in one of our professional affiliations, including ALPFA, Ascend and NABA. In most cases, PwC reimburses for annual professional affiliation memberships for client service professionals. Check with your Talent Consultant for your team’s policy. I want to build my inclusion acumen • Participate in an Inclusive Leadership and Belonging session -- a multi-faceted training initiative to help partners and staff understand the impact they have and the role they play in creating a sense of belonging for all. • Get insights from psychological science to help improve the decisions we make in life and at work through Outsmarting Human Minds and PwC discussion guide. • Learn how unconscious bias can impact behavior and decisions. Watch Blind spots 4REAL, a four-part interactive video series based on a fictional company and featuring a team who is influenced by unconscious bias and explore our Blind spots video series. • Check out this Coaching Across Differences Vantage Playlist to be a more inclusive leader. • Get a behind-the-scenes look at our people and the choices they make to live the lives they want in the Pursuit of Happiness podcast. • Check out upcoming Coaching with an Inclusive Mindset sessions in your market. • Listen to the Candid conversations: Respect in the Workplace podcast. • Watch webcast replays: Disability Caregivers | Professionals with Disabilities | All of us: A candid conversation about gender on International Women's Day 2019 I want to be a champion for diversity and inclusion • Take the CEO Action for Diversity & Inclusion I Act On pledge and commit to check your bias, speak up for others and show up for all. • Through our partnership with the UN Women's HeForShe initiative, we are working toward achieving global gender equality in the workplace and beyond. Join us by taking the HeForShe pledge. • Complete one or more Implicit Association Tests (IAT) and commit to talking about it with your colleagues. • Check out the calendar of upcoming Inclusion Network events Our Initiatives Disability & Caregivers Gender LGBT+ Minorities Parenting Veterans

Prepared Parent Types of Leave Family leave is your time to spend with your loved ones - whether welcoming a new child or caring for a close family member at a difficult time. At PwC, we care about the whole person, which is why we are committed to benefits for our people that support a broad range of family needs. These benefits provide flexibility and enable our team members to be there for their families and be their best at work. Parental Leave Effective July 1, 2018, our parental leave policy includes: Eight weeks of parental leave for both women and men: Note the majority of women will be eligible for 16 weeks including parental leave and maternity disability or adoption leave (see related policies below). Phased return to work option after parental leave: An innovative solution to the transition challenges parents face in coming back to work. Parents have the option to work 60%, at full-time pay, for an additional 4 weeks immediately following a parental leave. The National Leave Center (NLC) and our short-term disability insurance carrier provide comprehensive information about additional time you may be eligible to receive, such as maternity disability leave and unpaid leave. The NLC recommends that you contact them between your fifth and eighth months of pregnancy—or about two months before you expect to go on leave—to complete necessary paperwork. To schedule a leave, please contact the National Leave Center at 1-877-OnLeave(1-877-665-3283) or email National_Leave_Center@us.pwc.com. Parental Leave information Short-Term Disability Typically, if you meet the eligibility criteria, you are eligible to receive approximately eight weeks of fully paid short-term disability benefits (or 10 weeks for a c-section delivery). Please see the formal policy for more information. To schedule a leave, please contact the National Leave Center at 1-877-OnLeave(1-877-665-3283) or email National_Leave_Center@us.pwc.com. Short-Term Disability information Family Caregiver Leave Effective July 1, 2018, eligible PwC staff can request four weeks of paid time off that can be used to care for a spouse, child, or parent, who has a serious health condition, as defined by the Family & Medical Leave Act (FMLA). Please see the formal policy for additional information. To schedule a leave, please contact the National Leave Center at 1-877-OnLeave (1-877-665-3283) or email National_Leave_Center@us.pwc.com. Family Caregiver Leave information Extended Job-Protected Leave information The federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) assures leave time to eligible staff for certain family situations, including caring for a newborn or newly adopted child. Some states have Family Leave Acts (FLAs) that may be more generous—check with the National Leave Center. FMLA allows you up to 12 work weeks of job-protected leave during a 12-month period. For eligible parents who take parental or adoption leave, the firm will provide a single, continuous period of up to 14 weeks of job-protected leave beyond FMLA. Job-protected leave runs concurrently with paid leave and the initial portion of any unpaid leave elected. Contact the National Leave Center at 877-On-Leave (877-665-3283) for eligibility and details. Extended Job-Protected Leave information Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) Leave of absence career roundtable option Leave of absence career roundtable program We're flexible We believe that people are more productive at work when they've got the flexibility to manage their lives outside the office. It can be tough to juggle our personal and professional priorities. It's a long-standing challenge in professional services—and one we continually work to improve at PwC. Workplace flexibility is about working creatively to manage our lives at work and at home. We all need some form of flexibility. Nearly all our people have a degree of give-and-take in their schedules. It could be as casual as shifting a few hours to accommodate a child's doctor appointment, or as formal as a reduced schedule. That flexibility helps us make time for the things that matter most in our lives. We also recognize the need for formal Flexible Work Arrangements. FWAs offer a creative way to provide high-quality service while enjoying additional personal freedom. With the agreement of the client and team, participants can choose from a variety of formal options: Reduced Hours: Working less than a standard week Flextime: Work hours move earlier or later PwC@Home: Working at least 60% of the time at home PwC Offsite: Working less than 60% of the time at home Job-Sharing: Two people fulfill the responsibilities of one position Compressed Work Week: Standard hours compressed into fewer work days Flexibility2 Spark page Practical advice for returning to work Guidelines for maternity leave are pretty straightforward, but it can be a different story for your transition back to work. So many personal factors go into deciding when and how to return to work that it's hard to give broad recommendations. Instead, consider some of these questions: How much paid time off is available to you, including short-term disability, firm-paid parental leave and vacation time? How much unpaid time off is available? How much time off, if any, do you want to take or can you afford? What type of assignments or projects are you working on, and how will they affect your leave? Will your leave take place during your busy season? Do you want to take all your available paid parental leave at once, or take part of it and use the remainder to transition back slowly? Will you request a reduced schedule or other flexible work arrangement? How could you make that work? What day of the week do you want to come back? Would a day other than a Monday be easier for you? Do you plan to nurse your baby? The Nursing Moms' Program can help you decide and manage your nursing. Have you conducted a "trial run" of your childcare before you actually return to work? For example, have the babysitter start a week before you return to work, or drop the baby off at your day care center for a few hours to help him or her get adjusted. Have you arranged emergency backup care in case your regular provider falls though? Some people recommend preparing two backup plans, just to be safe. Pregnancy Planner First trimester Educate yourself on all the firm's benefits and programs for pregnancy and parenthood; visit Resources and Life Events on My Rewards and Benefits. Visit Benefits Express and navigate to "Health and Well-Being." Then see "Resource Materials" for detailed information about medical benefits (including prenatal care programs), short-term disability, FMLA and more. Contact your medical carrier to find out about special benefits and programs. Start planning your leave, but understand it will probably change as you work through your career goals, figure out your finances and weigh all your options. Think about when you'll tell your supervisor. Most people wait until after the first trimester before making their pregnancies public, but your health, comfort level or your health care provider's advice might dictate different timing. It's hard to keep such great news secret. On the other hand, nine months is a long time to have everyone asking how you feel! Let your health, relationships and best judgment be your guide. Second trimester According to experienced moms and dads, now is a good time to begin thinking about childcare options. You might not come to a decision yet, but you may narrow the choices. Also, you can place yourself on waiting lists, since popular daycare centers often have long ones. Start making appointments to visit potential childcare sites. This will help you determine the best type of care—in-home versus center-based—as well as what fits your budget. For this, you'll need to explore all your options. Contact LifeWorks. Not only can they provide referrals and other resources, they also offer confidential counseling to assist in your decisions. If you travel, think about when to cut back—your doctor may instruct you when it's no longer safe. If you plan to nurse your child or want help deciding whether to nurse, register for the Nursing Moms' Program. It's available to all PwC women, as well as the spouses and domestic partners of PwC professionals. Program guidelines recommend enrolling after the fifth month of pregnancy. Can't fit into your clothes? Checkout Perks at Work for possible discounts at maternity stores or websites. The site is updated regularly, so it's worth an occasional visit. Revise your leave plan based on what you now know. Third trimester The National Leave Center (NLC) recommends that you contact them approximately two months before your leave begins. Call 877-ON-LEAVE, and they'll send a comprehensive packet of information about your disability and parental leave benefits, including all the forms you'll need. They'll also provide a leave specialist who can answer questions before and during your leave. Reach out to your local HR representative or Diversity Leader to find out about local resources. There may also be Parenting Circles or Women's Networking Circles that can offer additional support. If you plan to continue nursing when you return to work, ask your local HR representative or Office Services Leader about accessing the Mothers' Room. If a Mothers' Room isn't available, they can help make accommodations for you. Consider the projects, responsibilities and people most likely to be affected by your absence. They'll surely appreciate careful planning on your part. Schedule a meeting with your partner or LOS leader to discuss your intentions, including your ideal return-to-work plan. Now's a good time to discuss the possibility of returning to a flexible work arrangement—perhaps a part-time schedule or telecommuting. Keep working on your plan, and realize that no matter what you think now, you can't actually know how you'll feel until after you have your baby. Send a note to all relevant parties, including the NLC and HR, to inform them of your plan. Include your last scheduled day at work and your anticipated return date. To help manage expectations, you might want to include how often—if at all—you'll be checking in. Keep in mind you should not generally perform work during your leave. If you want, include your contact information (you never know—someone may want to send a gift!). Remember that additional unpaid leave (beyond the job-protected period) requires HR approval, and you need to contact the NLC about any changes to your return-to-work plans. Change your voicemail and email messages to reflect your leave status. Indicate an alternative contact person and number. Don't forget to submit your last time and expense reports, and consider how to handle any recurring expenses. Advise the NLC of any last-minute changes. Childcare isn't child's play If there's one thing working parents agree on, it's that finding quality, affordable childcare is a tough challenge—and there aren't any shortcuts. You have to visit many locations, interview many people, and in the end, go with your gut. Childcare Discounts The firm has arranged discounts with leading childcare organizations across the country. Parents must request the discount and may be required to show a PwC ID or business card. Childcare discounts information Bright Horizons Care Services PwC partners with Bright Horizons to provide our partners and staff with limited access to their national network of emergency backup child care centers as well as free access to Sittercity.com and Years Ahead for a comprehensive database of sitters, pet caregivers, elder care resources, and more. Backup Care Reimbursement FY19 care: For care starting July 1, 2018, Bright Horizons administers the backup care reimbursement program, which provides up to $1,000 annually of reimbursement for backup care when your regular child- or elder-care provider is not available. The PwC Backup Care Reimbursement Program may be used to offset the cost of emergency back-up care provided by an agency, in-home caregiver, friend, relative or neighbor and can be used for child, spouse and adult/elder care when your normal care is not available. Partners and staff scheduled to work a minimum of 20 hours per week are eligible for the program -- full-time partners and staff can receive up to $1,000 in reimbursement per fiscal year (July 1-June 30), reimbursement is pro-rated for part-time partners and staff. In order to receive reimbursement, complete and submit the reimbursement form, which can be found on the Bright Horizons websitehttp://www.careadvantage.com/PwC. Sittercity and Years Ahead Memberships Bright Horizons has partnered with Sittercity and Years Ahead to bring you a comprehensive database of sitters, pet caregivers, elder care resources, and more. Here are a few additional benefits you will receive with additional family support from Bright Horizons: Waived Membership Fee: Bright Horizons will waive the annual membership fee to the Sittercity database Free Background Checks: Every sitter on the database is subject to a basic background check at minimum To register for the waived membership fee, visit https://www.sittercity.com/pwc. Emergency back-up care at Bright Horizons Centers School closed? Sitter on vacation? Travelling for business and need care in another city? Bright Horizons back-up care is available toPwC partners and staff. You can use your back-up care benefit in a Bright Horizons network center, anywhere in the United States. Here is what you will receive: Support for your family with up to 12 annual days of backup child care at subsidized rates. Center-based care is $25/child or $35/family. Reserve care up to 30 days in advance, or even the morning of the day your family needs care. To even better support you and your newest family member, you have an additional 10 days of backup care to use until your baby is 12 months old or during the first full year of adoption. Partners and staff who work a minimum of 20 hours per week are eligible. There is a co-pay of $25 per child per day, or a maximum of $35 per family per day. One use equals one day used by each child. In compliance with the Firm’s tax treatment of fringe benefits, each use of an emergency back-up daycare center will also qualify as $50 of taxable income. This $50 daily value is not an out of pocket co-pay, rather, the $50 will be added to your annual taxable income, which is consistent with the current tax treatment of the Back-up Reimbursement program. To register for Bright Horizon’s center based BackUp Care, or to reserve care for your child, visit http://www.careadvantage.com/PwC. Please enter employer access code: PWC and password: pwc4backup Back-Up Care Mobile App: The Bright Horizons BackUp Care app makes registering for and reserving backup care easy. Features include uploading center-based care forms via the camera to easily bring to centers across the US, scheduling backup care at a center instantly, and more. Download the app from the PwC App Store or the Android for Work Play app. Health and Dependent care flexible spending account Please click here for Health and Dependent care Flexible spending account LiveWell resources A LiveWell specialist can help you find emergency care, as well as day-to-day care. LiveWell provides an array of confidential counseling and referral services, plus resources on birth, parenting, child care, elder care and other issues. Contact LiveWell at 1-877-PwC-4You (877-792 4968) or https://www.liveandworkwell.com/content/en/public.html (access code: pwc). Programs, policies and resources Childcare Discounts Disability Caregivers Network Diversity Leaders Bright Horizons Care Services Extended Job-Protected Leave Flexibility2 Talent Network Flexible Work Arrangements Full Circle Dental and Vision Flexible Spending Account Leave of absence career roundtable option Mother's Rooms Nursing Moms' Program Parental Leave Short-term Disability Prenatal Care Programs Expecially for adoptive parents Parental Leave for adoption and surrogacy Adoption & surrogacy financial assistance We're here to support you We know that the challenges our parents face require flexibility and support on the part of the firm. So we developed our programs in response to what our new parents told us they needed most of the time to bond with a new baby, flexibility to juggle often competing priorities, and support in finding resources whether for childcare, schooling or counseling. What's more, we constantly evaluate these programs to assess that they're working.
Partner Candidate Leadership Development Experience (PCLDE)

record.pwc_description:
It’s one thing to have a digital mindset—it’s another to live it in everything you do—in our business, with our clients and in every aspect of how we work. We've taken the story of our digitization and are bringing it to life through the services and solutions we offer our clients and the tools we use to make our lives easier.
Technology brings us closer, makes us faster, helps us work smarter.

The Digital Hub is the central resource for everything you need to take your Digital Upskilling game to the next level. Digital Upskilling is a key component of our Your Tomorrow strategy -- helping us build the skills we need to thrive in a digital world and accelerate our progress as infinite learners by removing limits on what, where, when and how we learn.

record.pwc_title: Be well, work well: The Well
record.pwc_description: Everyday behaviors and habits focused on fueling our four dimensions of energy - proven to help us become and sustain our best selves.

Digital Lab is a first-of-its kind, online, One Firm technology sharing community that serves as PwC's internal “storefront” for the full breadth of the firm’s digital solutions across Automation, Data, and Artificial Intelligence (AI). It allows our people to develop new digital assets and/or co-create solutions with peers -- which can then be leveraged and scaled across the firm.

record.pwc_description: Responsible Business Leadership is our commitment to make an impact in our communities and deliver business value by helping create a more equitable society.

Our Total Rewards strategy serves as our guiding principle to support both our people and business strategies. Total rewards refers to your entire rewards package – from base pay and bonus to career milestones to non-monetary rewards, health and wellness benefits, and retirement programs. They are designed to recognize the growth you've achieved and the contributions you've made.
You can change your PwC 401(k) Savings Plan contribution election, view your vacation balance, check your compliance responsibilities, view a summary of your dental benefits, and much more on Me@PwC.

Program that provides financial rewards for engaging in healthy and responsible behaviors.
Information about our Firmwide calendar and how to charge time for holidays and firmwide shutdowns.
record.pwc_body: Holiday schedule In FY20, the firm offers 13 paid holidays (this includes seven designated national holidays, four extended firm holidays and two floating holidays*). The number of floating holidays that newly hired staff receive depends on their date of hire (see Floating Holiday Entitlement for New Hires below). All offices will be closed on the following days: 07/01/2019 Vacation Day/Floating holiday* 07/02/2019 Vacation Day/Floating holiday* 07/03/2019 Extended firm holiday 07/04/2019 Independence Day 07/05/2019 Extended firm holiday 09/02/2019 Labor Day 11/28/2019 Thanksgiving 11/29/2019 Day after Thanksgiving 12/24/2019 Vacation Day/Floating holiday* 12/25/2019 Christmas Day 12/26/2019 Extended firm holiday 12/27/2019 Extended firm holiday 12/30/2019 Vacation Day/Floating holiday* 12/31/2019 Vacation Day/Floating holiday* 01/01/2020 New Years Day 05/25/2020 Memorial Day Additional information Extended Firm Holidays The firm will provide four extended firm holidays this year. The firm will close for the July 4 holiday from July 1-5. In conjunction with the extended July 4 holiday week, all staff will either use a vacation day or floating holiday on July 1 and July 2, resulting in a full week shutdown. The firm also will close on Dec. 24, 26 and 27. In conjunction with the extended year-end firm shutdown, all staff will use either vacation days or floating holidays on Dec. 24, 30 and 31, resulting in an extended 9-day break from Dec. 24 through Jan. 1, 2020. Note: Scheduled holidays (including extended firm holidays) are non-transferable (i.e., if a scheduled holiday occurs during a leave of absence, you will not be entitled to time off to make up for the scheduled holidays you missed). *Floating holidays This number may vary in some offices due to recognition of local holidays (e.g., Patriot's Day). Floating Holiday Entitlement for New Hires The number of floating holidays that a newly hired staff member is entitled to depends on their date of hire. The table below sets forth the policy for staff members hired after July 1, 2019, indicating the number of floating holidays earned. Date Hired Days Earned 7/1/19-12/31/19 2 1/1/20-3/31/20 1 4/1/20-6/30/20 0 Generally, floating holidays may be taken any time during the fiscal year. However, you should get approval prior to taking a floating holiday to ensure no client or scheduling conflicts exist. Using a floating holiday could be for President’s Day, Martin Luther King, Jr. Day or religious or ethnic observances. Providing this discretion to partners and staff members underscores the firm’s commitment to well-being and the belief that all our people should have the flexibility to decide what days fit their diverse needs. Floating holidays must be taken prior to June 30 each fiscal year as they do not accrue or roll into subsequent years unless otherwise mandated by state or local law. Individuals who terminate their employment are not paid for unused floating holidays unless otherwise mandated by state or local law. Early Office Closings At the discretion of the Market Managing Partner, offices may close two hours early the day prior to a firm holiday. Using the Lost Time code Use the Lost Time WBS code for early office closing hours in the following circumstances: • You are working in the office, from home or at a client site. • To account for hours of your regular workday that fall within the specified early office closing hours. FY 19 Holiday Schedule FY 19 Holiday Schedule Charge Codes Holiday WBS code: 9.0000001.002 Use for firm designated national, extended firm, and floating holidays. Lost Time WBS code: 9.0000001.006 Use for early office closings (refer to the Lost Time section).

record.pwc_description: LiveWell Resources offers a wide range of information and services that can be accessed easily and confidentially by partners, staff and eligible family members. No enrollment is necessary and there is no cost for using the services.
Access more than 8,000 gyms and studios nationwide and find a fitness routine that works for you, choosing from five membership levels.
record.pwc_body: Gympass Find an activity you love with Gympass. Our new partnership with Gympass makes getting active even easier and helps fuel the physical dimension of Be well, work well, part of our Your Tomorrow strategy. There are five membership levels available to choose from, ranging from $9.99 to $149.99 per month, with no long-term contracts, enrollment fees or cancellation penalties. With access to more than 8,000 gyms and studios nationwide, you can find a fitness routine that works for you — whether you’re close to home, traveling for work or on vacation. See FAQs and this video to learn more. Registering for Gympass 1. Visit PwC’s App Store on your iPhone/iPad or the Google Work Play Store on your Android; download the Gympass App or visit gympass.com/us/pwc-us on your desktop, and click Activate My Account. 2. Click on Sign up for free. 3. Enter your name, PwC Google email address* and create a password. 4. Explore the different plans and gyms/studios within the Gympass network. Once you have created your Gympass account, you can view gyms and studios provided within each of the Gympass membership levels on the app before completing your Gympass purchase. (You won’t be charged at this point; you’ll only be charged if you select a plan, proceed to checkout and enter your credit card information to complete your transaction.) 5. Once you have identified the plan you’d like to enroll in, add the plan to your basket. Note that as a first time Gympass user, you’ll receive 7 days for free. After the 7-day trial ends, your monthly membership will begin automatically and your credit card will be charged. If you wish to make any changes prior to your monthly membership charge, you will need to do so within those 7 days. 6. Proceed to checkout and enter your credit card information. You’ll receive a ‘Purchase Complete’ email with details of your Gympass membership plan. * If you are a new hire, it may take 10-14 days before you can register with Gympass due to file transmission timing. Family registration After you complete your Gympass purchase, you can invite your eligible family members to join Gympass from the Gympass app or website. Simply complete their information, and your family member will receive a welcome email from Gympass. Each family member chooses their own membership plan with its own monthly cost, and completes their purchase with a credit card — they do not have to choose the same plan or the same payment option as you. You can select up to five Gympass memberships per family. Family members cannot register for Gympass if the partner or staff member does not join the program. Visiting a gym or studio Once you complete the registration, click the Search or Classes icon and locate a facility. (Note, you do not have to enter your credit card information in order to review the list of classes and gyms.) If you don’t see a gym or studio included in the Gympass network, you can nominate it to the Gympass team, and they will contact that facility and keep you posted. If your gym is added, Gympass will advise you. Gympass will work closely with your nominated facility; however, some facilities may not choose to opt into the Gympass network. Check out the FAQs for nomination details. Support Contact Gympass over the phone (844-478-4744), Live Chat or email. Support is available Monday–Friday, 8 a.m.-8 p.m. ET. To access Live Chat: log into your account, click “contact us” and select chat function. * If you are a new hire, it may take 10-14 days before you can register with Gympass due to file transmission timing.

record.pwc_description: PwC’s Student Loan Paydown (SLP) benefit provides eligible associates and senior associates with $100 per month (or $1,200 per year) paid directly to their student loan servicer for up to six years, or until promotion to manager (whichever comes first).
You can change your PwC 401(k) Savings Plan contribution election, view your vacation balance, check your compliance responsibilities, view a summary of your dental benefits, and much more on Me@PwC.

Gender initiatives-TEST We are committed to gender equality. That means we strive to attract, retain, develop and advance women at all stages in their careers. Through our initiatives we provide opportunities for our women to develop and lead, take on new challenges and thrive throughout their careers. We focus on creating an inclusive culture that develops women to be future leaders. We take action by: Educating our people about gender dynamics in the workplace. Connecting women with allies, learners, members and supporters through our Women’s Inclusion Network (WIN). Supporting the advancement of women by embedding diversity and inclusion into all aspects of the career lifecycle. Providing developmental programs for top performing women. Focusing on women in technology as part of the Your Tomorrow strategy. Resources All of us: A candid conversation about gender on International Women's Day 2019 (webcast replay) Candid conversations: Respect in the Workplace podcasts HeForShe Building Gender IQ online course developed by PwC and UN Women LeanIn educational resources Prepared Parent (for policies and programs) Pursuit of Happiness podcast Talent Acquisition initiative -- Women's Consulting Experience Women in Tech -- Digital Upskilling: Tech While You Trek Find additional resources in the Women Inclusion Network (WIN) Office of Diversity Contacts Resources All of us: A candid conversation about gender on International Women's Day 2019 (webcast replay) Candid conversations: Respect in the Workplace podcasts HeForShe Building Gender IQ online course developed by PwC and UN Women LeanIn educational resources Prepared Parent (for policies and programs) Pursuit of Happiness podcast We are #PwCProud to be an IMPACT corporate champion of the UN Women’s HeForShe initiative. VN - 421 Naveen Test #PwCProud: Movin’ on up to #6 on People’s ‘Companies That Care’ list We’re #PwCProud to be recognized for demonstrating respect, compassion and concern for our people, our communities and our environment. People magazine recognized PwC in its annual “50 Companies That Care” list, and we’re No. 6 , up from No. 42 last year! To identify Companies That Care, People partnered with Great Place to Work®. Rankings are based on surveys representing over 4.5 million employees’ experiences of how their workplaces have made a difference in their lives and in their communities. Rankings also reflect Great Place to Work's assessment of the generosity of each organization's benefits, philanthropic and community support, with particular focus on activities occurring in the last year. Our continued investment on diversity and inclusion, well-being and Responsible Business Leadership, and Digital Upskilling through Your Tomorrow — reinforced by our purpose and values — underscores our commitment to create a place where everyone is supported and encouraged to become the best version of themselves. Through the survey responses, here’s what was heard: We offer generous benefits and wellness perks. We provide generous leave policies and an innovative phased return-to-work program. We offer an unprescribed number of sick days for eligible staff, to take time off for their own illness or injury. We support our people in times of need. The PwC Charitable Foundation, Inc. makes contributions to our people and their immediate families in times of unexpected financial hardship. It also helps fund charitable organizations where our people volunteer. We listen and build trust. We’ve held hundreds of Inclusive Leadership and Belonging sessions. They are helping us learn what we can do to make the experience for every person at PwC even better. We continue to lead the way on this and are doing our part as individuals and a firm through the CEO Action “I Act On” pledge to personally commit to support inclusion and driving action at PwC and in our communities. We make flexibility and well-being work … every day. We know that flexibility is good for both our people and our business. Our people have the flexibility they need where, when and how they work. And we’re committed to a focus on well-being through Be well, work well, as part of our caring culture. Volunteerism is at the heart of our giving culture. As part of our Responsible Business Leadership strategy, we encourage our people to volunteer for activities that are important to them. We couldn’t have earned this recognition without building an exceptional culture together — one that inspires all of us to deliver our best. We’re excited to see our contributions have an impact, and that we’re making a difference for our clients, our communities and one another.
